title: Endgame walkable town hub with shops and zone select
description:
## Vision
After completing the 4-zone campaign, players unlock a walkable pixel-art town hub (expanding the current campfire scene). Characters move around freely, visit shops, manage gear, and select zones + difficulty.

## Inspiration
- Halls of Torment: inventory management between runs, zone/difficulty select
- Deep Rock Galactic: persistent gear, rare drops feel rewarding

## Key Features
- **Walkable town**: Player character moves around a small pixel-art town area
- **Shop buildings**: Walk up to NPCs/buildings to open shop interfaces (weapons, armor, consumables)
- **Zone select**: Pick any unlocked zone from a board/map in town
- **Difficulty tiers**: Per-zone difficulty settings (Normal, Hard, Nightmare, etc.)
- **Persistent inventory**: Rare gear drops during runs carry back to hub
- **Gear system**: Equippable items that persist between runs (unlike per-run skill picks)
- **Rare drops**: Legendary/epic items from bosses or rare enemies that feel rewarding

## Architecture Notes
- Current campfire scene (index.html) is the foundation — expand canvas area
- Campaign mode (current linear progression) stays as-is for new players
- Endgame mode unlocks after beating all 4 zones
- Keep per-run skill picks as the in-run progression; gear is the between-run progression

## Current State
- Campfire hub exists with 4 characters, pixel art, music
- Linear campaign: Cyberpunk -> Gothic -> Forest -> Cosmic with shops between
- Save system already tracks currentWorld, gold, skillPoints, class stats

comments.author: matt
comments.text:
## Economy Balancing Needed
Current economy snowballs: gold persists on death, shop upgrades are multiplicative (1.15^5 = 2x damage), but enemy scaling is linear (+3% HP per upgrade). After 1-2 failed runs you accumulate enough gold to steamroll. For endgame hub, consider: gold loss on death (keep a %), steeper enemy scaling curves, upgrade cost escalation, or a gear durability system.

title: Create System Infection music video -- stickdeath arena battle
description:
## Vision

A stickdeath arena battle music video synced to "System Infection" (102 BPM, D minor, ~3.5 min).

### Visual Arc (matching song structure):

**Intro (Patterns 0-3) -- The Arena Awakens**
- Dark empty arena, single spotlight flickers on
- A lone stick figure drops into frame, lands in combat stance
- Camera slowly pulls back revealing the arena walls, crowd silhouettes
- As the riff builds, opponent stick figures start appearing at the edges

**Verse 1 (Patterns 4-7) -- First Wave**
- 1v3 combat begins -- the protagonist vs first wave of enemies
- Synced to the chugging rhythm: punches/kicks land on beat
- Ragdoll physics on defeated enemies -- bodies fly and crumple
- The sneering square-wave melody = taunting between hits

**Chorus 1 (Patterns 8-11) -- Chaos Erupts**
- Full arena brawl -- 1v6+, weapons start appearing (staves, chains)
- Big melody hits = big finishing moves (uppercuts, spin kicks)
- The D5-C#5-Bb4-A4 motif = a signature combo move every time it plays
- Crash cymbals = impact flashes / screen shake

**Verse 2 (Patterns 13-15) -- The Rematch**
- Tougher enemies -- bigger stick figures, some with weapons
- More defensive fighting, dodges synced to the bII tension riff
- Chromatic bass grinding = the ground cracking/arena shifting

**Chorus 2 (Patterns 16-18) -- All-Out War**
- Same energy as chorus 1 but more enemies, more chaos
- The hook motif = the signature combo returns, even more devastating

**THE BREAKDOWN (Patterns 19-22) -- The Moment**
- Pattern 19 (The Drop): Everything stops. Bodies litter the arena. Protagonist stands alone, breathing. Near silence.
- Pattern 20 (Building Tension): New enemies start emerging from shadows, slowly circling. Heartbeat-like bass pulses.
- Pattern 21 (The Rage Builds): Protagonist enters a power-up state -- glowing outline, screen rumbles
- Pattern 22 (FULL RAGE): ABSOLUTE CARNAGE. Blast beat = frame-by-frame rapid hits, bodies flying in every direction. The protagonist becomes an unstoppable force. Maximum ragdoll physics.

**Final Chorus -- Eb Minor Key Change (Patterns 23-24)**
- The key change hits like a level-up. Arena transforms (color shift to match Eb minor mood?)
- A final boss-sized enemy appears
- The transposed motif = the final signature combo, now even more powerful
- Sustained Eb5 at the end = the finishing blow lands in slow motion

**Outro -- Shutdown (Pattern 25)**
- Slow-motion motif one final time as the boss falls
- Hard cut to black on the silence. No credits roll, no fade -- just stop.

### Technical Notes
- Depends on stick fight physics engine being complete
- Should use the audio tracker playback position for beat sync
- Key sync points: crash cymbals (pattern starts), motif appearances, the breakdown silence
- Consider particle effects for impacts, screen shake on heavy hits

### References
- Xiao Xiao flash animations (classic stickdeath)
- Madness Combat series (arena escalation)
- One Punch Man fight choreography (the breakdown moment)
close_reason: Closed

title: Add dual-format support to ChipPlayer.load()
description:
## Problem
The 4 survivors song files (survivors-*.json) are saved in the tracker native format but ChipPlayer.load() only accepts the compact format. This causes music to silently fail - song.seq is undefined so no notes schedule.

## Format Differences
- Tracker native: sequence, patterns[].channels (sparse event objects {r, n, i, d})
- ChipPlayer compact: seq, patterns[].ch (dense [midi, inst] arrays or null)

## Solution
Update ChipPlayer.load() in games/audio-tracker/playback-engine.js to detect and handle both formats. If song.seq exists use as-is (compact). If song.sequence exists normalize on the fly: sequence to seq, expand sparse channels into dense ch arrays, map instrument fields if needed.

This is preferred over re-exporting songs because new songs will keep getting saved in tracker-native format.

## Files to Modify
- games/audio-tracker/playback-engine.js - add format detection and normalization in load()

## Verification
1. Load any survivors arena (arena.html?world=cyberpunk) - music should play after game starts
2. Verify volume is reasonable (musicGain is 0.12 vs SFX master 0.4)
3. Test that compact-format songs still work
4. Test in organ.html and tracker that nothing breaks

## Context
- engine.js already has loadMusic/startMusic/stopMusic wired up
- Each theme file already declares song path
- arena.html already loads playback-engine.js before engine.js
- Music starts on startGame(), stops on victory/game over
close_reason: Dual-format support added to ChipPlayer.load() and campfire music wired into hub
